loan.name: Nelia

texts.en: To make a living, Nelia P. runs a general store selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 55 years old, married and has five grown-up children. She is from the village of Bagong Sikat, Alicia, Isabela. Nelia has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Nelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Nyaga

texts.en:
Nyagah K. is 41 years old, married and has nine children aged between 3 and 25 years. His business is along a busy highway in a place called Spaki in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well-known for its many many tourist-attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches.
He sells such items as chicken feeders, metal basins, cookers and metal buckets in a business he has engaged in for the last 25 years. He sells to the local people and nearby institutions. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is lack of sufficient supply of raw materials to make the items that he sells.
He is using his loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy scrap metal and clay for use in making the items that he sells. He hopes to give his children quality educations and he also hopes to grow his business to a wholesale one someday. He describes himself as very friendly to his customers.

loan.use: Scrap metal and clay

loan.name: John Seruma

texts.en:
46-year-old John Seruma K. is a dedicated, affable and foresighted gentleman with a clear sense of what he wants for his business in the short and long term. Before he began this business he was more inclined to carpentry, but for the last 10 years he has worked hard in his metal fabrication and welding workshop in Kayunga Town. John mostly makes products like metal doors, gates, windows and deckers, and in a week makes 100,000 shillings. The happily married father of five also concurrently operates a mowing business.

With this loan of 2,000,000 UGX, John wants to purchase more scrap metal. This, he says, will aid him in making most of the products he sells, such as metal gates, beds and windows.

In the photo John Seruma K. is seen standing besides some of the metal products he has made.

loan.use: To purchase more scrap metal

loan.name: Arnold

texts.en: Arnold G.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. He is 40 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Bayabo East. Arnold has been in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Arnold joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise. Arnold is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his seventh loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Noli

texts.en: Noli Y. is from the village of Bayabo East. He is 31 years old. Noli is single. To make a living, Noli raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Noli has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately 45,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per harvest. In 2007, Noli joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Noli is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Noli from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loan.name: Konoweka Womens Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
For the last six years, 46-year-old, good-humored and affable Bonny N. has been enjoying good spells of financial success running her cereals and fresh fruits business in Kyamumbi-Kayunga. She has been working vigorously to establish a strong foothold for herself in the local market over these years, given the competitive nature of her kind of business.
Bonny has not stopped short of any measures aimed at enhancing her business prospects. She took root with savings from her farming business. In a week, her profits add up to 25,000 shillings.
Bonny, a married mother of six, also operates a school.
With this loan, she wants to buy more bags of cereals and fruits that she will be able to sell on a large scale.

loan.use: The purchase of more bags of cereals and fresh fruits for resale

loan.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes D. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 42 years old. Lourdes is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes owns & operates a fish selling business, selling fish in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2009, Lourdes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Lourdes from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loan.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha Y. is from the town of Talibon. She is 47 years old. Editha is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Editha owns & operates a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Editha has been engaged in her business for over 10 years. She says she hopes for her business to prosper so that she would also be able to sustain the education of her children.
Editha joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Editha from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to make improvements to their house.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loan.name: C 4366 Dutsindubukene Group

texts.en:
Denyse is 32 years old, married with one child and takes care of one dependent. Denyse is the president of a group called C4366 DUTSINDUBUKENE and this group is commonly known for selling fruits and vegetables. The business hours are from 5 am to 8 pm every day. Denyse and her team has been in this business for about four years.
Their capital is still too low to expand meaningfully. To end this, they are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, Denyse and her team will invest more in the same business to the extent that they will start wholesaling to the retailers from their environmental area. If successful, Denyse and her team will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loan.use: To purchase a large quantity of fruits and vegetables

loan.name: Ochirbat

texts.en: Ochirbat P. is 57 years old and lives with his wife and son in Hovd province, western of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is retired and his son is unemployed. Ochirbat makes locks and sells them at a local market. He and his wife began their business in 2003 and the couple works hard to provide for their family's quality of life. Ochirbat is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more spare parts for their business.

loan.use: To purchase inventory and supplies.

loan.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria B. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 36 years old. Maria is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Maria owns & operates a business manufacturing & selling clay products to local businesses and community members. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2009, Maria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Maria is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will again be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the second loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.

loan.name: Atyrgul's Group

texts.en:
Atyrgul B. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and married. She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter is married and lives separately with her own family. The younger son helps his mom to breed livestock and the first son went to work in Russia to earn some money. Atyrguls husband works as an operator at the bus station. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, he bought a bull and resold it after fattening. With money received from the loan, Atyrgul wants to purchase a sheep for breeding.
Jiydegul U. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and a widow. She has raised four daughters and a son. The first daughter is married and lives separately with her own family, the second child studies at university and the other children are at school. In order to make money, Jiydegul sells fruits and vegetables at the market. In this way she makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase 100 kg of potatoes and 100 kg of cucumbers to resell at the market. In the future, Jiydegul plans to expand her business and save money to be able to pay for her childrens education.
Erkingul J., 44, is married. She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter and the first son study at university, and the second son is at school. Four years ago, Erkingul left her job, bought a pavilion and started to sell convenience goods. In this way she makes 4000 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase some goods (10 kg of confectionery and 6 packs of drinks) in order to sell them in her pavilion.
Omurbek C. is 48 and married. He has two sons and two daughters. The older son helps his father to sell milled products on the market, the first daughters studies at university and the other children are at school. Omurbek has been selling milled products for fifteen years. In this way he makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase 30 tons of milled products and 500 kg of coal in order to resell them at a higher price.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To purchase a sheep.

loan.name: Emile

texts.en:
Emile is 34 years old and married with five children between 5 and 13 years old. Emile is commonly known for selling clothes and he has been in this business for about 15 years. The starting business hours are 7 am and the closing hours are 6 pm every day.
Emile wishes to start selling styles for women but unfortunately, his capital is still too low. To end this, Emile needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, as his business will be expanded, Emile will hopefully increase the number of customers as well as profits. With these profits, Emile will keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loan.use: To purchase different styles of women's clothes

loan.name: Terbish

texts.en:
Terbish D. is 61 years old and lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional housing tent. Her son operates a second-hand car sales business while her husband is retired but helps with her business.
Terbish runs a stall and sells a variety of clothing and consumer goods at Norjin, one of the biggest markets in Ulaanbaatar city. In 2008, she began her business and after several years of stable earnings, she used her savings to expand her business.
Terbish is a very hardworking and decent person who manages her business as neatly as her bookkeeping. Her daily revenue reaches to 30,000 to 50,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) on average. She is very focused on making her business successful as it is the only source of income for her family. She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase different clothes so she can expand her product line.

loan.use: To purchase inventory

loan.name: Tumur

texts.en:
Tumur S. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Hovd province in the western part of Mongolia. The family lives together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.
He graduated from a technical college 30 years ago as a repairman and, seeing an increase in the car-repairing business, he planned to run one in his town with the help of his sons.
Tumur is requesting a 3,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase tools and equipment for his car-repairing business.

loan.use: To purchase tools and equipment

loan.name: Zenaida

texts.en: Zenaida B. is from the village of Simimbaan. She is 49 years old. Zenaida is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling health and medicinal products in the local community. Zenaida is just starting this business. In 2010, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly oarmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Tuvshinsaihan

texts.en:
Tuvshinsaihan B. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and child in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.
Tuvshinsaihan is a teacher; however, he also operates a taxi service between Hovd city and the Buyant sub-province. He began his business in 2007 and has gained a lot of experience since then. He is requesting a 1,200,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase parts to repair his car.

loan.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loan.name: Niyazi

texts.ru: Niyazi Ibrakhimovu 24 qoda. On ne jenat i jivet v regione Absheron vmeste so svoyey semyoy. V biznese prodaji produktov on rabotayet uje 4 qoda. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya pereprodaji. V budushem on xotel bi uvelichit prostranstvo svoyeqo maqazina.
texts.en:
Niyazi I. is 24 years old. He is single and lives in the Absheron region with his family. He has been selling produce for four years. Currently, he needs 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs for resale. In the future, he would like to expand the size of his shop.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying cattle

loan.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is a 50-year-old married man. Since 1984, he has been selling candies on a wholesale basis. Victor drives his van and passes through many villages on his way to sell his products. His clients are very pleased with his products, and say that his prices are very affordable.
This is Victors first time to request a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy an extra big variety of candies to attract kids attention as much as he can. Victor believes pleasing the kids is the best thing to do ever. He hopes to be the owner of a big wholesale candy store where everyone will visit and buy his products in spite of him passing by villages and clients. He said he hopes to keep his visits in the future in order to keep clients satisfaction and work hard on developing his career.

loan.use: To buy an extra big variety of candies

loan.name: Policarpio

texts.en: Policarpio V. is from the village of Bagong Sikat, Alicia, Isabela. He is 33 years old. Policarpio is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Policarpio sells branded and generic medicines. The main source of income for the business comes from selling manufactured medicines to local businesses and community members. Policarpio has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Policarpio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Policarpio is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Policarpio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

Leticia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leticia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loan.name: Luvina

texts.en:
Luvina P. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 37 years old, married and has 7 school-aged children. Luvina owns & operates a business, manufacturing & selling clay products to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.
In 2009, Luvina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the third loan taken out by Luvina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees.

loan.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loan.name: Tabylkan's Group

texts.en:
Tabylkan D. is the leader of this group. She is 56 and is married. She has raised two daughters and three sons. Her daughters are married and live separately with their families; her two older sons work in Bishkek Telecommunication Company and the younger son lives with his parents and helps them with housework.
Tabylkan and her husband have been breeding livestock since 1995. Every day Tabylkan sells 9-10 liters of milk and makes 1300 soms per month. With the loan she wants to purchase five sheep to increase the number of livestock.
Shairkul S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 48 and is a widow. She has two sons and a daughter. Her oldest son works in Bishkek in a sewing workshop and the other children study at school. Shairkul works in the sewing workshop. She applied for a loan because she needs money to install a door and purchase paint to repair her house. Karyibek A., 49, is married. He has three sons and a daughter. All of his children, apart from his first son, live and work in Bishkek. Karyibek and his wife work in retail. In 1995 they began selling meat and now they sell convenience goods. In this way Karyibek makes 1500 soms per month. With the loan he wants to purchase various goods for resale. In the future he plans to purchase a pavilion and expand his business. Amantur B., 53, is married. He has an eighteen-year-old daughter who studies at school. Amantur works as a security guard; he started to breed livestock in 2008. That year his relatives gave a sheep as a present on his daughters birthday. Amantur applied for the loan because he wants to purchase two sheep to increase his livestock numbers. In the future he plans to build a shed and save some money to be able to pay for his daughters education at university.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase sheep

loan.name: Huseyn

texts.en:
Huseyn H. lives in Vahdat. He is 56 years old, married, and has three children. He has a vocational education as a driver. He worked in his trade for ten years. Now he works in the market. He makes pies and sambusas (savory filled pies) for sale. His wife helps him. He has vast experience in this. He is taking out a loan to expand his business. He wants to lease a space and open a bakery.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Expand the business

loan.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 34 years old and married with three children who are 2, 7 and 9 years old. Odette makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her small shop as her picture indicates. Odette has been in this business for about five years and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 7 pm every day.
Although Odette has been in this business for about five years, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully. To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, she will invest in the sale of foodstuffs mainly cassava, Irish potatoes, potatoes, beans, etc. With these foodstuffs, Odette will hopefully earn a lot of profit and this profit will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loan.use: To buy foodstuffs including cassava, Irish potatoes, potatoes, beans, etc

loan.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda T. is from the village of Bagong Sikat, Alicia, Isabela. She is 50 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Imelda owns & operates a livestock business, raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells a raised animal.
In 2006, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

loan.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loan.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros P. is from the village of Bayabo East. She is 47 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Milagros owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP during the harvest season.
In 2007, Milagros joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Milagros from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Vasila

texts.en:
Vasila S. lives in Yavan. She is 54 years old, married, and has eight children. She has a higher education as a teacher. She worked in her specialty for fifteen years. Now she is works in sales. She has a shop where she sells hairpins, costume jewelry, and various knick-knacks. She has been doing this for thirteen years. She is taking out a loan to increase sales. With her profits, she would like to marry off her son.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Increasing sales

loan.name: Arsenio

texts.en:
Arsenio Y. is from the village of Bayabo East. He is 53 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Arsenio owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 29 years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP per harvest.
In 2007, Arsenio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Arsenio is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Arsenio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Nabingola Dembe Group, Mubende

texts.en: J. Stephan is the leader of his lending group in Mubende. He is 35 years old, married and has 5 children, 4 of whom go to school. He also takes care of dependants. Stephan sells maize, beans and cassava from Nabingola and Kibaale in a roadside market. Stephan is committed and honest and in a month he is able to make a profit of 360,000/=. Stephan is also a farmer and he needs a loan to support his business of 10 years that has been a family venture from the very start. He needs a loan to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loan.use: to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loan.name: Joyeuse

texts.en:
Joyeuse is 43 years and married. Joyeuse is commonly known for selling a variety of school and office items. She has been in this business for about five years and the hours of the business are from 8 am to 6 pm every day.
Joyeuse needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business. With this loan, Joyeuse will purchase more office as well as school items with the purpose of satisfying the demands of her customers. If successful, Joyeuse will earn a lot of money, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loan.use: To buy a variety of office and school items

loan.name: Abunzubumwe No 2 Group

texts.fr:
Kanyamahamga Simeon ne a bugesera lEst du pays, mari,il a 3 enfants,il a 36 ans, son ain a 10 ans et son 3.5 ans et son niveau dducation est primaire. Il vit avec sa famille sake Bugesera. 2 parmi ses enfants vont lcole. Avec son mari ils travaillent pour faire vivre et amliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. il fait le commerce des habits dans le centre commercial de Sake qui est un centre rural mais qui commence tre dvelopp.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appel ABUNZUBUMWE NO 2, qui est un groupe dont les membres sont agri-leveurs et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Simeon et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en amliorant leurs conditions de vie et en amenant leurs enfants lcole. En fait, le groupe a contract un prt au sein dAmasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles de leur commerce et les revendre, une partie du profit est rinvesti pour maintenir la stabilit financire du groupe et pargner afin de prparer pour un bon futur.
texts.en:
Simeon Kanyamahamga was born in Bugesera in the eastern part of the country. He is married and has 3 children. He is 36 years old. His eldest child is 10 years old and his youngest is 3 and a half years old. He has a primary level of education. He lives with his family in Sake Bugesera. 2 of his children attend school. He works with his husband to provide for his family and improve its living conditions. He sells clothes at Sakes commercial center. Although it is a rural center, it is starting to grow. He belongs to a solidarity group called ABUNZUBUMWE NO 2. The members of this group are farmers who mutually guarantee each other. Simeon and his group work to improve their families living conditions and send their children to school. The group has contracted a loan within the Amasezerano Community Banking association to purchase the goods necessary to their business and sell them. Part of the profit is reinvested in order to maintain the financial stability of the group and save money in order to prepare for a good future.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase clothes for retail

loan.name: C4561 Twuzuzanye Group

texts.en:
Eugenie is 43 years old and married with three children. The first child is 20 years old, the next is 15 and the last is 11 years old. Eugenie takes care of one dependent who is 10 years. Eugenie owns a small business selling various styles of clothes. Eugenie has enough experience in this field because this is her fifth year of experience. The hours of her shop are from 8 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except one day in the week. Eugenie is group leader of her group, which is called TWUZUZANYE in the local language. This group contains 11 members with different businesses.
Now, Eugenie and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing more products for their business. With this loan, Eugenie and her group will be able to satisfy their customers, which will be one of the ways of earning more profits.

loan.use: To expand her business

loan.name: Aydin

texts.ru:
Ayidn A. jenat i imeyet 2 detey. Emu 52 qoda. Aydin pereselenec iz okupirovannoy territorii Azerbaydjana, oblasti Kalbadjar i seychas obosnovalsya v Khirdalane.
Eto vtoroye obrasheniye Aydina. On ochen blaqodaren za pervuyu ssudu v kotorom on prosil 1000 $ chtobi uvelichit pomesheniye eqo maqazina. No teper Aydin otkril kafe uje 2 qoda. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit stoli i stulya dlya svoyeqo kafe.
texts.en:
Aydin A. is married with two children. He is 52 years old. Aydin is a refugee from an occupied territory in Azerbaijan, region of Kalbadjar, and now lives in Khirdalan. This is Aydins second loan. He is very grateful for the first loan in which he requested $1000 in order to expand his store. Aydin opened a caf two years ago. Now he needs 2000 AZN to buy tables and chairs for his caf.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying tables and chairs

loan.name: Nabingola Dembe Group B, Mubende

texts.en: S. Jamadah is the leader of his lending group in Mubende. He is 30 years old, married and has 4 children, 3 of whom go to school. He also takes care of dependants. Jamadah sells maize and beans from the roadside market in Nabingola. Jamadah also sells cattle that he buys from the villages and sells to the township for meat and rearing. He is a committed and honest man and, in a month, he is able to make a profit of 190,000/= from produce and cattle sales. Jamadah felt that this was the easiest and most convenient business for him to do and does not regret his decision to do this. He needs a loan to be able to buy more beans and maize for resale. He believes that this will help him pay his childrens school fees as he has managed to build a house out of his savings.

loan.use: to buy more beans and maize for resale.

loan.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn A. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 32 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Roselyn owns & operates a livestock business, raising ducks to produce and sell eggs. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month.
In 2010, Roselyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Roselyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her immediate family.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loan.name: Bombooti Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BOMBOOTI a vu le jour depuis la cration du Banc Villageois il ya 9 ans. Il fait partie du Banc Villageois de NEMA2. Il est compos de 05 femmes du mme quartier. Il a pour but de renforcer la solidarit de groupe en particulier et de s'entraider entre membre en cas de difficult de remboursement en gnral.
Madame Georgette KALAMON lextrme droite de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est ge de 47 ans. Elle est marie et mre de 09 enfants en charge.
Elle envisage de vendre des lgumes. Elle a une bonne exprience dans ce domaine dactivit. Elle compte s'approvisionner Ziguinchor et revend sa marchandise domicile au march Tilne dans le dpartement de Ziguinchor.
Son nouveau crdit de 250.000 francs CFA lui permettra dacheter de choux pomm, de carottes, de navets, de piments etc.
Son objectif est de dvelopper son activit. Appuyer son mari sur les charges familiales tout en renforant son niveau dpargne.
texts.en:
The BOMBOOTI group was formed when the Banc Villageois of NEMA2 was created nine years ago. It consists of five women from the same neighborhood. Specifically, its goal is to strengthen the bond of solidarity within the group and more generally, for the members to help each other in case of difficulties with loan repayment. Mrs. Georgette KALAMON, at the far right of the photo, is the head of the group. She is 47 years old. She is married and a mother to nine dependent children. She plans to sell vegetables. She has good experience in this field. She expects to get her stocks in Ziguinchor for resale at her local market in Tilne, in the Ziguinchor department. Her new loan of 250,000F CFA will allow her to buy cabbage, carrots, turnips, peppers, etc. Her goal is to expand her business, help her husband with the familys expenses, and increase her savings.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy vegetables

loan.name: Muhammed

texts.en:
He is hilarious and always keeps a sparkly smile on his face. B. Muhammed, 43, is a happily married father of 8 and has been successfully overseeing his retail shop in Kimenyedde-Kayunga for the past 20 years. The decisions he has taken in regard to strengthening the smooth running of his business have had a big impact and explain why he has been able to achieve this longevity. He has educated all his children with profits from this business.
What started off as a small shop is now a fully-fledged, flourishing, retail shop that brings him 300,000 shillings a month. The fact that he has been able to create and strike a pleasant working relationship with his clients also explains his success. His plans for the future are to expand his business into wholesale and to give his children the best possible education they can have.
With this loan, Muhammed wants to purchase an array of general stock for his shop. In the villages commodities like soap, sugar, salt, candles, paraffin and bread are favorites. That is predominantly what he is planning to purchase with this loan.

loan.use: to purchase stock for resale

loan.name: Hien's Group

texts.en:
Hien T. N. is 35 years old. She lives in Pho Cho village with her husband and two children. She is a farmer. She not only grows rice but she sells porridge in the market. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 2,500,000 Vietnamdong (VND) or 3,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2007. She feels happy because she can save money every day, every week. The last cycle, she borrowed 4,578,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount punctually. Now she would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND to expand her shop. She is the leader of a fivemember group loan from SEDA.
About other borrowers in her group:
Trang T. H. H. is 24 years old. She sells souvenier presents. She would like to borrow 6,758,000 VND to expand her shop. Vinh T. T. is 54 years old. She sells pork in the market. She would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND to invest in her business. Dung T. P. N. is 25 years old. She would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND to breed pigs. H. T. H. is 42 years old. She would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to breed poultry.

loan.use: To expand her shop

loan.name: C4577 Abanyamurava Group

texts.en:
Solange is 26 years old and married with two children who are 2 and 4 years old. Solange is the leader of a group called Abanyamurava and this group is commonly known for selling foodstuffs. This is their third successful year in this business and the business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.
After three years of experience in the business, their capital is still too low to expand meaningfully. To end this, they need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company and this loan will allow them to increase the quantity of their sales as well as the profits. If successful, this team will keep reinvesting and start saving for a better future for their business as well as their families.

loan.use: To buy foodstuffs such as potatoes, beans, Irish potatoes, rice, etc...

loan.name: Nassinkar Group

texts.fr: Le groupe de solidarit de NASSINKAR est cr depuis la mise en place du Banc Villageois de NEMA2. Il est compos de six femmes du mme et de mme. Elles se sont organises en groupe depuis l'inauguration du Banc Villageois pour renforcer leur solidarit et leur amiti. Madame Marie Pierre M. tout fait droit de la photo est la responsable du groupe. Elle est ge de 50ans. Elle est marie et mre de 08 enfants et a la charge de 03 autres enfants. Elle a 09 fois de fois de suite reu de crdit auprs de CAURIE-MICRO FINANCE. Elle fait un petit commerce de lgumes. Elle achte des carottes, des choux, des navets etc.. Avec son prt elle va renforcer son niveau dapprovisionnement en achetant plus de lgumes et escompter des bnfices plus importants. Elle participe lamlioration des conditions de vie de sa famille par la nourriture, la sant, lhabillement et le payement de la scolarit des enfants.
texts.en:
The Nassinkar solidarity group has been in existence since the Nema2 Banc Villageois was set up. It is made up of six women who are also members of the banc. When the banc was formed, they organized the group to strengthen their cooperation and their friendship. Mme Marie Pierre M., at extreme right in the photo, leads the group. She is 50. She is married, has eight children of her own and cares for three others. She has had nine loans from CAURIE Microfinance. She runs a small business in vegetables, buying carrots, cabbages, turnips and so on. With this loan she will build her inventory by buying more vegetables, and she hopes for increased profits to enable her to better meet her family's needs as far as food, health care, clothing and school fees are concerned.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Acheter des lgumes

loan.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina A.'s main source of income comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 62 years old, married and has six grown-up children. She is from the village of Brgy. Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. Rosalina has been in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase products to sell. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her ninth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offerings

loan.name: Nayitna Group

texts.fr: Le groupe NAYITNA a vu le jour depuis la cration du Banc Villageois il y a 9ans. Il est compos de 04 femmes toutes issues du mme quartier. Il a pour but de renforcer la solidarit lentraide entre membre Madame Simone D. droite de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est vendeuse de lgumes. Elle a une bonne exprience dans ce domaine dactivit. Elle s'approvisionne Ziguinchor et revend sa marchandise domicile et dans diffrents marchs de la ville Avec son prt elle va acheter des choux, des carottes, des navets, tomates etc. Son objectif est de promouvoir son activit, de renforcer ses pargnes et de soutenir son mari dans les diffrentes charges familiales.
texts.en:
The group Nayitna came into being since the Banc Villageois was created nine years ago. It is composed of four women, all from the same district. Its goal is to bolster solidarity and the mutual aid among its members. Ms. Simone D. (at the right in the photo) is the group's leader. She is a seller of vegetables. She has good experience in this business domain. She stocks up in Ziguinchor and resells her merchandise out of her home and at the different markets in town. With her loan, Simone is going to buy some cabbage, carrots, turnips, tomatoes, etc. Her goal is to advance her business, to boost he savings, and to support her husband to cover the different family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying vegetables

loan.name: Norma

texts.en:
Being a loyal member of a Kiva first field partner in the Philippines (ASHI), Norma N. had been receiving loans since 2000. Loans she received then have enabled her to have several businesses that she managed. First, she started a cow & hog fattening business and with her next loans, she opened a party needs shop and rented sewing machines. To market her products, she sells directly to people in their village and in a public market. Now, Norma is requesting another loan from ASHI to support her businesses and to grow them further until such time that they become profitable and stable. For her party needs store, she wants to increase her inventory for the convenience of her customers who live around their village.
Norma happily handles her career being a wife, mother and businesswoman. Her desire to give her children a better kind of life in the future inspired her to have her own businesses and augment her husbands irregular income.
Norma is one of the very good members of ASHI who is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP to realize her dream of buying more inventory for her party needs store and purchasing seven sewing machines to rent. Profit from these kinds of businesses is quite good compared to other businesses that Norma has tried. Because of the profits she gained from her businesses, Norma has enabled her two daughters to graduate with a degree. Additionally, she wants to support the education of her son through college so he has a better career in the future. With her passion for giving her children a better future, Norma is willing to work hard and help her husband earn money through her businesses.
Norma is motivated by her desire for personal development so that one day she can be self-reliant in her businesses. Norma enjoys the system of work groups that is implemented by ASHI. She has benefited from hearing about the experiences of her fellow group members and appreciates that the process for securing a loan has been convenient for her.

loan.use: To buy more stock for her party needs store and purchase seven sewing machines to rent.

loan.name: Altannavch

texts.en:
Altannavch D. is 38 years old and lives with her parents and siblings in Baganuur, an outer district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rented house. Altannavch operates a business where she sews traditional Mongolian and a variety of western clothes. She began her business in 2002 and, since then, has become established in the local business community. She hopes to become even more successful so that she can provide for her family in the future.
She is a responsible and honest woman and is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan so that she can purchase a sewing machine for her business.

loan.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loan.name: Sainte Jeanne D'arc Group

texts.fr: Le groupe de solidarit SAINTE THRSE fait partie du Banc Villageois des femmes Catholiques de la Paroisse de LOUGA. Il est cr depuis trois ans. Il est compos de 12 femmes toutes issues de la mme communaut ecclsiale de base. Elles sont trs engages dans les activits de la Paroisse. Madame lisabeth S., droite de la photo est la prsidente du groupe. Elle est ge de 40ans. Elle est veuve et mre de 4 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois depuis son inauguration linstar de ses camarades Elle fait un petit commerce de produits halieutiques, dhuile de palme et de jus de citron. Elle pratique cette activit depuis plus de 5ans. Son lui permettra dacheter des poissons schs et/ou fums, des huitres sches, de lhuile de palme et du jus de citron. Son objectif est de renforcer son activit. Elle prend lentire charge de la nourriture, la sant et le payement de la scolarit de ses enfants
texts.en:
The solidarity group, Saint Therese, is part of the Village Bank of the Catholic women of the Louga Parish. It was created three years ago. It is made up of 12 women all coming from the same basic church community. They are very involved in the activities of the parish. Mrs. lisabeth S., to the right of the photo, is the president of the group. She is 40 years old. She is widowed and the mother of 4 children. She has been a member of the Village Bank since its opening, following the example of her friends. She runs a small shop of fishing products, palm oil and lemon juice. She has run this business for more than 5 years. Her loan will allow her to buy dried and/or smoked fish, dried oysters, palm oil and lemon juice. Her goal is to strengthen her business. She is fully in charge of the food, health and school payments of her children.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy palm oil and lemon juice

loan.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean damascene is 39 years old and married. Jean damascene sells a variety of foodstuffs such as sorghum, beans, peas, maize, etc. He has been in this business for about 10 years and the hours of his business are from 7 am to 8 pm every day.
Jean damascene needs to shift his business from his residential area to the main market. To end this, he needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. This loan will allow him to purchase more foodstuffs for sale. Jean damascene hopes that with the use of this loan, if he manages to go and operate his business in the main market, his profits will increase to the extent that the living style of his family will also improve.

loan.use: To purchase a large quantity of foodstuffs such as rice, maize, beans, etc

loan.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice was born in 1975. She is married with two children. Alice owns a business selling various styles of clothes and traditional materials to be used for keeping milk and so on. This business is located in her residence. This is her fifth year of success in her business. The hours of her daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day.
Alice is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business. With this expansion, Alice will be able to satisfy her clients. Alice expects to earn more profit as long as her customers are satisfied. With this profit, hopefully, Alice will buy her own house.

loan.use: To buy different styles of clothes

loan.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga S. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 49 years old, married and has 8 school-aged children. Dominga owns & operates a manufacturing business, making & selling clay products to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 33 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.
In 2009, Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the third loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loan.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
Mai T. N. is 37 years old. She lives in Xom Huong village, Co Loa commune with her husband and two children. She and her husband are farmers. They grow rice and they also sell meat in the market. They have a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietamdong (VND). Mrs Mai has had this job for many years. She has participated in SEDA since 2005. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND for her business.
About other borrowers in her group: Chung T. N. is 58 years old, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to breed poultry and raise vegetables. Toan T. N. is 58 years old. She has a store. She would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND to expand her store.

loan.use: to small business

loan.name: Bataa

texts.en:
Bataa N. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Baganuur, an outer district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own apartment. His elder daughter is a student while his wife helps him with make traditional Mongolian shoes by hand.
He began his shoe making business in 2006 and his shoes are well known and valued by his customers for their quality and design. Bataa would eventually like to expand his shoe making business and create his own shop in the future. Bataa is an honest, reliable and hard working person who is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase materials for a large number of shoes.

loan.use: To purchase inventory

loan.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma K. N. is a young man who runs his business in the Central Business District of Mombasa. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions, not forgetting the Indian Ocean white beaches.
He sells mobile phone accessories and also does phone repairs. He has been in this business for three years now and he says that his business is very profitable. The major challenge that Juma has to deal with is limited space and power rationing. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more phone accessories to meet high customer demand. He hopes to grow his business and become a phone dealer, whereby, he will open many outlets and provide employment. He describes himself as a very social person.

loan.use: to buy phone accessories

loan.name: Mere Theresa Group

texts.fr: Le groupe de solidarit MRE THERESA fait partie du Banc Villageois des femmes Catholiques de la Paroisse de Louga. Il est cr depuis trois ans. il est compos de 11 femmes toutes du mme quartier et de la mme communaut ecclsiale de base. Madame Irne K. est la responsable du groupe. Elle est lextrme gauche de la photo. Elle est ge de 53 ans. Elle est veuve et mre de 5 enfants et a la charge de 4 autres enfants. Elle est restauratrice. Chaque soir elle se rend au foyer de la mission Catholique de Louga pour prparer et vendre de la soupe de viande de la grillade de viande. Elle prpare galement des sandwichs et des poulets Avec son prt elle va augmenter son niveau dapprovisionnement en viande et en poulets et acheter plus de condiments. Elle prend entirement toutes les charges familiales, nourriture, sant, habillement, scolarit etc.
texts.en:
The Mother Theresa solidarity group is part of the Banc Villageois of the Catholic Womens association of the Louga parish. It has been created three years ago. It is composed of 11 women living in the same neighborhood and belonging to the same church community. Mrs. Irne Kampla is the group leaders. She is on the far left in the photo. She is 53 years old, a widow, the mother of five children, with four other children also in her care. She prepares food for sale. Each evening she comes to the parish house of the Catholic mission of Louga in order to cook meat soup and grill meats for sale. She also prepares sandwiches and cooks chicken. With this loan, she would like to expand her stock of meat and chicken and to purchase more condiments. She has full responsibility for all family expenses, such as food, healthcare, clothing, school fees etc.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchasing meat, chicken and food condiments

loan.name: Thoa

texts.en: Thoa T. K. T. is 53 years old. She is alone. She has broken her leg. She has a beverage store and her main income is profits from sales. She has an income of about 2,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and has always repaid punctually. She wants to borrow money form SEDA forever because, then, she can keep saving money. In her last cycle, she borrowed 7,630,000 VND and has completely repaid this amound. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,930,000 VND to expand her store.

loan.use: to expand her store

loan.name: Sanabarhon's Group

texts.en:
Sanabarhon S. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and is married. She has a son and two daughters, all of whom are of preschool age (in Kyrgyzstan children start school when they are seven). Sanabarhons husband works in construction. When he is free he helps his wife with cattle breeding. They also own some land and cultivate different fruits and vegetables. Sanabarhon also sells dairy products every day. In this way she makes 2000 soms per month. With the loan she wants to purchase a cow and a calf for breeding.
Shairgul A., 31, is married. She has two sons and three daughters. All her children, apart from the youngest daughter, study at school. Shairguls husband sells fruit and vegetables wholesale and he makes 8000 soms per month. Shairgul breeds cattle. She applied for the loan because she wants to purchase a cow and a calf for breeding. In the future she wants to purchase a big truck to help her husband to start exportation of fruit and vegetables to neighboring countries.
Shairgul E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35 and married. She has a six year old son who has just started school. Shairguls husband works in construction and earns 5000 soms per month. Shairgul herself is engaged in cattle breeding. She also sells dairy products every day. She makes 3500 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to repair her house. In the future Shairgul wants to increase her cattle numbers.
Tursunai T., 33, is married. She has a son and a daughter, both of whom study at school. Tursunai works as a waitress. Her husband went to work in Russia. Tursunai also breeds cattle and sells them after fattening. With the loan she wants to purchase a calf for breeding.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase a calf

loan.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 32 years old and is married with four children. She is well-known as a self-employed businesswoman selling styles of clothes for men as well as for women. She has been in this business for about four years and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.
Francine needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, she hopes that she will improve her business by adding modern styles which undoubtedly will increase her sales as well as her profits.
With the earned profits, Francine will keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loan.use: To add modern styles of clothes

loan.name: Hue

texts.en: Hue B. N. is 34 years old. She lives in Xom Huong village. She is married with two children. She has a disk store. She has had this job for 5 years. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2004. In the last cycle, she borrowed 6,758,000 VND and repaid this amount punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to expand her store.

loan.use: to expand her store

loan.name: Dufatanye Group

texts.fr:
Theoneste N., ne bugesera secteur Sake lEst du pays, mari, il a 4 enfants, il a 40 ans, son ain a 17 ans et son dernier enfant 10 ans et son niveau dducation est primaire. Il vit avec sa famille sake Bugesera. Tous ses enfants vont lcole. Avec son pouse ils travaillent pour faire vivre et amliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Il fait le commerce des habits pour dtail et pour la couture dans le centre commercial de Sake qui est un centre rural mais qui en voie de dveloppement.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appel DUFATANYE, qui est un groupe dont les membres sont tous commerants et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Theoneste et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en amliorant leurs conditions de vie et en amenant leurs enfants lcole. En fait, le groupe a contract un prt au sein dAmasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles de leur commerce et les revendre, une partie du profit est rinvesti pour maintenir la stabilit financire du groupe et pargner afin de prparer pour un bon futur.
texts.en:
Theoneste N. was born in Bugesera, in the Sake district in the Eastern part of the country. He is 40 years old, married with four children of whom the eldest is 17 and the youngest 10 years old. His level of education is primary. He lives with his family in Sake Bugesera, and all his children attend school. He earns his living together with his wife and they seek to improve their familys living conditions. He sells clothing retail and for tailoring in the commercial area of Sake, which is a developing rural centre. He belongs to a solidarity group named Dufatanye, whose members are all merchants and provide each other mutual guarantee. Theoneste and his group work to ensure their familys subsistence, improve their living conditions, and provide schooling for their children. In fact, the group has obtained a loan from the Amasezerano Community Banking association, to buy items for resale in their commerce. Part of the profit is reinvested to ensure the groups financial stability, and put into savings to prepare for a prosperous future.

Translated from French by Ren McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy clothing for retail sales and for tailoring

loan.name: Phuong

texts.en: Phuong T. N. is 39 years old. She is married with two children. She grows rice and also makes rice cake to sell. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2004. In the last cycle, she borrowed 6,758,000 VND and repaid this amount punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy rice to make rice cake.

loan.use: to buy rice to make rice cake.

loan.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma L. is from the town of Banga. She is 43 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Gemma owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Like other mothers, she works hard to be able to send her children to school and dreams of them completing college.
Gemma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the first loan taken out by Gemma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loan.name: Ancilla

texts.en:
Ancilla was born in 1970 and is married with four children between 5 and 12 years old.
Ancilla owns a small business selling various products such as juice, cooking oil and so on and has an experience of three years in her business. She employs one person from her community as a helper so that her business runs well. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Saturday.
Now, Ancilla is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business. With this loan she hopes to earn more profit to be used in her daily activities.

loan.use: To invest in expanding her business

loan.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda P. is from the town of Banga. She is 43 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Nilda owns & operates an agricultural business, planting & harvesting corn for sale. She dreams for her family to have better living conditions.
Nilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Nilda from CEVI.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loan.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora L. is from the town of Banga. She is 31 years old. Leonora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She hopes to have good health for her so she could keep up with the hard work required at maintaining their farm. She says she only wants the best for her family.
Leonora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leonora from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loan.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is 54 years old and is married. She struggles in selling a variety of foodstuffs, mainly cassava flour, corn flour, rice, sugar, etc. This is her fifth successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.
Despite five years of experience in the business, Constance's capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, with the result that her profits are still too low. To end this, she is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.
Once given this loan, Constance will expand her business through purchasing additional foodstuffs to sell. With these additional foodstuffs, her sales as well as her profits will increase. Thus, she will also be able to improve the living style of her family.

loan.use: To buy a large quantity of foodstuffs to sell

loan.name: Bavubuka Twekembe-Mukono Group

texts.en: 37-year-old K. Fred has been running a fishing and fish selling business in Bunankanda-Mukono for the last 15 years. With monthly profits of 200,000 shillings, he has been able to support his family with this business. All his 3 children are happy and in good schools and his stable marriage has also played a major part in the successful running of his business. He says his wife has always been there whenever he needed her help. Fred was inspired by a close friend to try his hand at this business and since then he has never looked back. His first business, charcoal selling, though still running, is now secondary to fishing. He makes a larger profit fishing so he has never regretted making fishing his primary business. With this loan, this long planning, reserved and enterprising gentleman wants to purchase more fish in bulk to resell and consequently earn more profits.

loan.use: The purchase of more fish to resell.

loan.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn S. is from the town of Banga. She is 60 years old. Merlyn is married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Merlyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She also helps her husband maintain their rice farm and selling their harvest.
Merlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Merlyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
