From the town of Cetro Napu, Tudela Mis. Occ., Jovita M. is a 68-year-old married mother of seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Jovita owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over seven years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jovita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 10000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan, her sixth, of 50000 PHP for the same purpose. Jovita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Jesusa D. is from the village of Gusa Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. This 39-year-old married mother of two school-aged children owns and operates a general store selling daily food in the local community. Engaged in her business for eight years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Jesusa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 8000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital and for the tuition of her two children. This loan will be Jesusa's seventh from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To buy additional products and goods and to pay tuition fees.

location.town: Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loan.name: Erdene-Oyun

texts.en: Erdene-Oyun T. is 27 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger a traditional housing tent. Her husband works for a local brick-manufacturing company. Erdene-Oyun manages a food trading business in her town. She started her business in 2008 and has used her earnings to purchase a fridge. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more food products to sell at retail prices.

loan.use: To purchase more food products for resale

loan.name: Chantrea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantrea V. is 25 years old and her husband, Mr. Bunthorn Pov, is 29 years old. They have been married since 2002 and have two children one son and one daughter both of whom are still young. The family lives on an island in Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.
Chantrea runs a grocery store at her home. She has just delivered a baby. Her husband has been a blacksmith for ten years. She is applying for a loan of $400 to purchase a motorcycle for her brother to drive to work.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her brother

loan.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma B. is from the village of Bandera. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Elma owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Elma has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Elma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kheng S. and her husband, Mr. Som-oun Nhem, have been married since 1962 and have seven children two sons and five daughters. All of their children are now married, and one still lives with the family. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Kheng buys silk products from her fellow villagers and transports them to sell in other provinces far away from her home. Her husband is a primary school teacher. She has received a Kiva loan several times already. She is now requesting another loan, for $1,000, in order to continue expanding her business by purchasing silk fabrics for resale.

loan.use: To purchase finished silk products for resale

loan.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng S. and her husband, Mr. Khoeun Khiev, married in 1978 and have four children one son and three daughters. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Heng and her husband are farmers. They grow jasmine flowers on their farmland near their house and sell the flowers in Phnom Penh market. Besides farming, Mr. Khoeun Khiev is also a fisherman. One of their daughters is married and wants to live outside the family home. Therefore, Heng is asking for a loan of $600 to help finance her daughter to build a house in which to live.

loan.use: To help finance her daughter to build a house

loan.name: Noeu

texts.en:
Mrs. Noeu T., aged 55, is a widow with five children three sons and two daughters. Her eldest daughter assists Noeu in her business, her next son is a chef, and the other three children attend school. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Noeu is a farmer. She grows vegetables on her farmland in the village. In addition, she wants to run a coffee shop as she will be able to earn extra income from this business. Therefore, she is asking for her first loan of $500 to build a shelter and buy materials to operate the business.

loan.use: To build a shelter and buy materials to run a coffee shop

loan.name: Ma. Luzviminda

texts.en:
Ma. Luzviminda D. is from the town of Surallah. She is 42 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Luzviminda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. She hopes to be a successful entrepreneur someday.
Ma. Luzviminda joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her sixth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About CEVI
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena F. is from the town of Surallah. She is 49 years old. Elena is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She says she works hard because she wants to increase her harvest.
Elena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elena is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Elena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional seeds and fertilizers

loan.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda L. is from the town of Surallah. She is 37 years old and married with three school-aged children. Rhoda's main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rhoda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.
Rhoda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Rhoda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loan.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loan.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita F. is from the town of Surallah. She is 41 years old and married with two adult children. Elenita's main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Elenita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.
Elenita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Elenita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loan.name: Channy

texts.en: Mrs. Channy T. is 27 years old and her husband Mr. Bin Khloeng, is 37 years old. They have been married since 2005 and have two young daughters. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Channy has been selling grocery items at her home for a year. She buys them from Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been driving a Tuk Tuk taxi for six years. Channy is asking for her first loan in the amount of $500 to purchase more groceries to sell.

loan.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell.

loan.name: Karya Murni Abadi Group

texts.en:
Putu D. (0) is a 38-year-old male living in the town of Melaya - Bali. Putu is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Karya Murni Abadi (PK-00108).
Putu is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Putu owns & operates a business venture raising pigs for sale. Putu has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 150,000 IDR a month from these activities.
In 2010, Putu joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Putu is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK. He is requesting a new loan of 1,000,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. The loan will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from MUK. Putu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for his children.
About MUK:
The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.
Putu D. (0) merupakan 38 tahun pria. Dia (laki-laki) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Putu adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Karya Murni Abadi (PK-00108).
Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Putu sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 3 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Putu menghasilkan sekitar 150,000 IDR. Dalam 2010, Putu bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Putu meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK. Dia (laki-laki) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,000,000 IDR.
Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.
Tentang MUK:
Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.
"

loan.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loan.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn C. is from the town of Sto. Nio. She is 28 years old, married and has a 4-year-old child. Evelyn owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Her wishes for the future are for her business to grow and to have a stable income.
Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Evelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

This will be the tenth loan taken out by Jaridian from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve it.

Lisa J. is from the town of Sto. Nio. She is 34 years old, single and loves helping her family. Lisa owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lisa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.
Lisa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lisa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Lisa from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

loan.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura K. is the leader of this group. She is 51 and married. She has raised two daughters and a son. The first daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the second is a student and the son works as a teacher. Ainura also works as a teacher at the same school. Her husband has been engaged in cattle breeding since 1995, after the collective farms broke up. Ainura applied for this loan because she needs money to pay for her second daughters education at university.

Nuruiza M., 51, is married. She has two daughters and a son. The first daughter studies at university, the second is at school and the son is preschool age under 7. Nuruiza and her husband have been engaged in cattle breeding since 1995. By selling some cattle, they were able to repair their house and purchase a tractor. Now Nuruiza hopes to obtain this loan because she needs money to pay for her daughters medical treatment. In the future, Nuruiza wants to see her daughters get married.

Aigul T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 49 and married. She has raised five sons: the three older ones are working, the fourth son is in the army and the youngest one studies at school. With money received from this loan, Aigul wants to pay for her sons education at university. In the future, she wants to purchase a house in Bishkek.

Sveta B., 43, is a widow. She has two daughters and a son. The older daughter and the son are at school and the younger daughter is not yet school age. Sveta hopes to obtain this loan because she needs money to cover the family's expenses. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to pay for her daughter's education at university

loan.name: Doreen

texts.en: Doreen is 28 years old and single. She has two children who are 5 and 9 years old. She has one dependant and she has a family of four people with whom she lives in a rented house in Hoima, Uganda. Her family goal is to educate her children. She has a beauty salon business. She has been in the business for four years. She started by plaiting hair. Eventually she opened her own salon for plaiting hair and now has started stocking cosmetics. Her business is seasonal and in the future, she expects to specialize in selling cosmetics and treating hair. The purpose of the loan is to purchase cosmetics for her salon business.

loan.use: To buy cosmetics

loan.name: Sari Usaha Group

texts.en: Ni Ketut P. is a 27-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali. She is the group leader of this ten-member group loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Sari Usaha (PK-10239). Ni Ketut is married and has one school-aged child. Ni Ketut owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month. In 2009, Ni Ketut joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,300,000 IDR from MUK. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Ni Ketut is now requesting a new loan of 1,300,000 IDR which will again be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her 2nd from MUK. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About MUK: The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. ***************************************************** Ni Ketut P. (0) merupakan 27 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Ni Ketut adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Sari Usaha (PK-10239). Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Ketut sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Ketut menghasilkan sekitar 200,000 IDR. Dalam 2009, Ni Ketut bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Ketut telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1,300,000 IDR dari MUK. Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,300,000 IDR. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK. loan.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loan.name: Sylvester

texts.en: Sylvester O. is 35 years old, single and does not have any children yet. His business is located in Mshomoroni, a residential area in Mombasa. He does carpentry and sells beds and sideboards. He has been in this business for the last two years and has two employees. He sells to local wholesalers and retailers. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he faces is customers not paying their debts on time as per their agreement. However, he works very hard to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of KES 80,000 to buy timber, backboard and nails to meet his customers' needs. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He is very hardworking, honest, determined and self-motivated.

loan.use: to buy timber, backboard and nails

loan.name: Janice

texts.en:
Janice G., photographed with one of her children, is from the town of Baclayon. She is 27 years old, married and has 4 young children. Janice owns and operates a business providing waste management and motorcycle transport services. Janice works hard to save for her children's education.
Janice joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janice is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Janice from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loan.name: Rwobusisi Bakyara Tukolerehamwe, Rukungiri. Group

texts.en: B. Godfrey is the leader of this lending group in Rukungiri. He is 37 years old and married with 3 children, all in primary school and he also takes care of other dependents. Godfrey is a boda boda (bicycle taxi) cyclist in Rukungiri, operating from the Bus Park stage for over 5 years. Most of his customers include district officials, local residents and school children. With this clientele, he is able to earn approximately 250,000 UGX as monthly profits, which help with his childrens school fees and general upkeep. Godfrey also has a banana plantation and he is able to sell his produce to merchants. He also has a retail shop that is mostly managed by his wife. He says that it has not been an easy road as he was a security guard before venturing into business. He is such a hardworking and dedicated man and he now owns three motorcycles with the help of loans. He needs a loan to help with upgrading his banana plantation and restocking his retail shop.

loan.use: Upgrading his banana plantation and restocking his retail shop

loan.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia J. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 29 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Aurelia owns a fishing business, operating a boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Aurelia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years. She dreams of having all her children finish college.
Aurelia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurelia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair the fishing boat and purchase additional fishing equipment. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Aurelia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

loan.name: Gaudiosa

texts.en:
Gaudiosa T. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 55 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Gaudiosa owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling various kinds of slippers in the local community. Gaudiosa has been engaged in her business for over 25 years.
Gaudiosa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loan.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina J. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 43 years old, married and has 8 school-aged children. Marcelina owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Her husband is a fisherman and she helps him sell his catch in her community.
Marcelina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and fishing materials. This will be the 16th loan taken out by Marcelina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loan.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samuel O. N. is thirty-five years old, married and has four children aged between ten and two years old. His wife helps him in running the business and they hope to grow the business and create employment for people.
His business is located at Mikindani estate in Mombasa and it is well known by the name Liera Tailoring. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches.
Samuel makes clothes for men and women of all ages. He also makes school uniforms, something he has engaged in for the last ten years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that he has limited space for his business and the area is also very dusty and this makes clothes dirty and spoils the sewing machine.
This is the reason as to why Samuel is taking a 30,000 KES loan to purchase a new machine and relocate to a new premise. He hopes to expand his business and employ people whom he will be directing. He describes himself as social.

loan.use: Buy a new sewing machine and pay rent deposit on new premises.

loan.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios T. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 47 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. She is a fish vendor. Her husband goes fishing and she sells all his catch in the market and around her community. She hopes to be able to acquire pigs that she could raise. Remedios joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. Restituta has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. Restituta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loan.name: Simon Kipngetuny

texts.en:
Simon Kipngetuny C. is a man of 57 years. He is married to Salina and they are blessed with four beautiful children. Simon and his wife are both farmers who live in the Mafuta area in the outskirts of Eldoret. He plants maize and wheat for resale after harvest and has been in this business for 10 years now. He gets a yearly income of 150,000 Kenyan shillings.
With this loan, Simon plans to buy fertilizer for his farm, and with the interest he is going to get, he plans to expand his farming business. In the future, he plans to feed, clothe and provide for his family and expand his farming business by renting more plots for planting maize and wheat.

loan.use: To buy fertilizer for his farm

loan.name: Rizalina

texts.en: Rizalina B. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 34 years old. Rizalina is single and has a 1-year-old child. To make a living, Rizalina runs a bakery. The main source of income for the business comes from baking and selling bread in the local community. Rizalina has been engaged in her business for over six years. Rizalina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rizalina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rizalina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients, like sugar and flour. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Rizalina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. loan.use: To purchase additional cooking ingredients, like sugar and flour

loan.name: Elisha Kiprotich

texts.en:
Elisha Kiprotich N. is a 28-year-old man. He is married to Teresa and they are blessed with two children who are aged 4 and 2 years. They live in the Mafuta area in the outskirts of Eldoret. Elisha is a farmer who plants maize and wheat for resale after harvest. Elisha has been farming for five years now and gets a yearly income of 120,000 Kenyan shillings.
This will be Elisha's third loan with KADET and he plans to use the entire loan to buy fertilizer for his farm. With the income he is going to get from the sale of the produce, he plans to pay school fees for his children.
In the future, he plans to educate his children to the highest level and also expand his business to large-scale farming.

loan.use: To buy fertilizer for the farm

loan.name: Nhoi Duoi1-3 Group

texts.en:
To T. H. is 46 years old and lives in Nhoi Duoi village with her husband and her son. She has a store and sells everything for everybody in her village. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).
She has participated in SEDA since 2009. For her last loan, she borrowed 2,375,000 VND and has completely and punctually repaid this amount. For this loan, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND to expand her store.
About the other borrowers in her group: Thuy T. D. is 36 years old. She would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to breed poultry.
Hong T. D. is 31 years old. She would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to invest in her store.

loan.use: to expand her store

loan.name: Nhoi Duoi 1-2 Group

texts.en:
Ngai T. N. is 40 years old and lives in Nhoi Duoi village, Co Loa commune. She is married with three children who are going to school. She is a worker. She has an aluminum window store and her husband works there. They have a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND.
This is the first time that Mrs. Ngai has participated in SEDA and she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to expand her store. She is the leader of a 6-member group loan from SEDA.
About other borrowers in her group: Vy T. D. is 37 years old. She would like to borrow 6,758,000 VND to invest in her store. Xuan T. T. L. is 23 years old. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to breed pigs. Be T. D. is 26 years old. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to breed poultry. Lan T. C. is 44 years old. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to breed pigs. Thoa T. N. is 28 years old. She sells vegetables in the market and wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND for her small business.

loan.use: in order to expand her store

loan.name: Anabelle

texts.en: Anabelle C. is from the town of Trento. She is 31 years old. Anabelle is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Anabelle raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Anabelle has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Anabelle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anabelle has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Anabelle is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the second loan taken out by Anabelle from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. loan.name: Biasha

texts.en:
Biasha is married to a businessman with two children: one attends school and the other one is too young for school. She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.
Biasha has been operating her business of selling kikois (pieces of colored cloth used as clothing) for the last seven years by going from door to door, women being her potential customers. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a bale of kikois.
Biasha hopes to build rental houses in future. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get financial support and improve her business.

loan.use: To purchase a bale of kikois

loan.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina R. is from the town of Trento. She is 53 years old. Cristina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Cristina raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also manages a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells basic food and daily-need products. Cristina has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Cristina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional store inventory. This will be the second loan taken out by Cristina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional store inventory

loan.name: Sahadatou

texts.fr: M. Sahadatou est ne le 13 Octobre 1961 Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bnin. Depuis prs de quarante ans, Sahadatou vit au quartier Kpondhou Cotonou, capitale conomique du Bnin. Sahadatou est marie SADIKOU Salami et est mre de trois enfants, tous scolariss. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins de la famille. Il y a environs trente ans que Sahadatou vend des draps, des rideaux et des foulards Dantokpa, march international du Bnin. Cette activit lui gnre des revenus l'aidant faire face ses diffrentes charges. Sahadatou achte ses produits Lom au Togo, et aussi au Nigria, Etat voisin du Bnin. C'est la deuxime fois que Sahadatou sollicite un concours financier auprs de ALID, en vue de renforcer son activit et de mieux faire face la demande de plus en plus grandissante de sa clientle.Sahadatou a bien rembours son premier crdit.
texts.en:
Sahadatou M. was born 13 October 1961 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. For the past 40 years, Sahadatou lived in the Kpondhou borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Salami Sadikou and is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. The couple share the handling of family expenses. Some thirty years ago Sahadatou began the retail sales of sheets, drapes and scarves in Dantokpa, Benins international marketplace. This revenue-generating activity helped her meet her financial responsibilities. She gets her products from Lom in Togo and also from Nigeria, a country neighbouring Benin. This is the second time Sahadatou is requesting financial support from ALID, seeking to strengthen her activity and respond to the ever-increasing demands of her customers. Sahadatou has fully reimbursed her first loan.

Translated from French by Ren McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy sheets, drapes, scarves, etc.

loan.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn P. is from the town of Trento. She is 37 years old. Evelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the second loan taken out by Evelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loan.name: Amatour Ramath

texts.fr: S. Amatour Ramath est ne le 14 Mai 1985 et vit depuis trois ans au quartier Sgbya Cotonou, capitale conomique du Bnin. Ramath a frquent l'cole jusqu' l'universit. Ramath n'es pas encore marie et n'a pas encore d'enfants. Ramath vit seule et assure seule ses diffrentes charges. Pour faire face ses charges, Ramath vend des voiles, des chapeaux de mariage, et de faon secondaire, des tenues franaises Dantokpa, march international du Bnin. Ramath achte ses articles au Nigria et Lom au Togo, Etats voisins du Bnin. Ramath exerce cette activit depuis trois ans et a obtenu une fois de prt ALID, prt qu'elle a bien rembours. Ramath dsire dvelopper davantage son activit et mieux rpondre aux exigences de sa clientle ; raison pour laquelle Ramath sollicite un deuxime crdit.
texts.en:
Amatour Ramath S. was born on May 14, 1985 and has been living for the last three years in the Sgbya district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has finished high school. She is not yet married and has no children. She lives alone and supports herself. In order to meet her expenses, Ramath sells headscarves, bridal hats, and, as a secondary activity, French-style clothing in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Ramath stocks up in Nigeria and in Lome in Togo, the countries neighboring Benin. She has been in this business for three years; she already had a loan from ALID before and duly repaid it. Ramath would like to expand her business and better meet customer demand, which is why she is seeking a second loan.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchasing headscarves, bridal hats and outfits

loan.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma P. is from the town of Trento. She is 36 years old. Gemma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also grows hogs for fattening and sale. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.
Gemma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and livestock feeds. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gemma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure and livestock feeds

loan.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo is a widow with five children. Three of her children go to school, the others work at small jobs. She own's a pub in Nalukolongo, selling all types of beer, local brew and gin. She buys crates of beer from delivery vans and kegs of local brew from Ndeeba. Teo uses public transport to and from Ndeeba.
Teo is going to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and kegs of local brew and gin. She has done this business for six years and has been with MCDT for five years. Besides this bar business she also owns a restaurant. She sells beer on a retail basis and she works seven days a week. Her main challenge is that there are many bars around her area of operation. Teo aspires to see her business grow and start selling on wholesale basis only. She decided to join MCDT because it was giving loans to women who live at the grass roots level. She resides in and owns her house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense in a month is food and school for her three children.

loan.use: To buy more crates of beer and kegs of local brew

loan.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda T. is from the town of Trento. She is 56 years old. Gilda is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Gilda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.
Gilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Gilda is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gilda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda T. is from the town of Trento. She is 34 years old. Linda is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Linda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Linda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years. She wishes to be a successful businesswoman and also dreams for her children to finish college.
Linda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Linda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Linda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm materials

loan.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is married to an electricia. They have two children and also take care of her younger sister. Harriet sells soft dinks to earn a living and works in a semi-urban city of Kawempe. She buys passion fruits and oranges from Owino market and uses public transport to and from shopping. Harriet goes shopping once a week. She will use this loan to buy more bags of passion fruits, sugar and oranges. Harriet has been in this business for eleven years. Besides this soft drink business she also owns a video library and sells from her home. She works seven days a week and her main challenge is that during rainy season she does not sell as much because the demand is low.
Harriet wants to make more profits from her business to be able to look after her family. She joined MCDT because they provide her with timely loans. She resides in and rents a two roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, school fees and food .

loan.use: To buy bags of passion fruits, sugar and oranges

loan.name: Rafiatou

texts.fr: R. Rafiatou est ne le 08 Septembre 1980 Cotonou, capitale conomique du Bnin. Rafiatou est marie AKILOCHO Idrissou, et est mre d'un enfant qui est scolaris. Rafiatou vit depuis sept ans au quartier Adoglta Cotonou, avec son enfant. Pour subvenir ses besoins et aux besoins de son enfant, Rafiatou vend des tenues pour enfants, des sous-vtements et des tissus bazins Dantokpa, march international du Bnin. C'est au Nigria et Lom, Etat voisin du Bnin, que Rafiatou achte ses articles. Rafiatou a dj bnfici d'un crdit auprs de ALID et a bien effectu le remboursement. Face aux exigences de sa clientle et leur demande sans cesse croissante, Rafiatou dsire renforcer son activit et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. C'est pourquoi Rafiatou sollicite un second crdit.
texts.en:
R. Rafiatou was born on September 8, 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to AKILOCHO Idrissou and is the mother of one child, who is in school. For seven years, she has been living with her child in the Adoglta district in Cotonou. To provide for herself and her child, Rafiatou sells outfits for children, undergarments, and damask cloth at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She purchases her goods in Lom and from Nigeria, a country bordering Benin. She has already had an ALID loan and has carried out the repayment of it. Facing the requirements of her customers and their ever-growing demands, Rafiatou would like to bolster her business and to increase her sales. This is why she is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying clothing for children, undergarments, and fabrics

loan.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Lucila P. is from the town of Trento. She is 39 years old. Lucila is married and has 3 school-aged children. She is involved in farming. She and her husband maintain their rice farm. Lucila also manages their sari-sari store located at their house. She sells stuff like sugar, vinegar and many other products. Like other entrepreneurs, she wants to be successful and have a stable income to sustain her family.
Lucila joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucila has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lucila is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and additional store inventory. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lucila from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve their living conditions.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizer & seeds for her rice farm and additional store inventory for her sari-sari store

loan.name: Zungumzo

texts.en:
Zungumzo S. M. is forty years old, married and has four children aged between twelve years and two and a half years old. His business is located along the Likoni-Lunga lunga road which is a busy highway and near the Likoni bus stop in Mombasa. It is well known by the name Z Auto parts. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites not forgetting the Indian ocean's white beaches.
Zungumzo sells auto spare parts and also owns a garage in which he serves taxis, Matatu owners and walk ins who have private vehicles. He has been in this business for five years now and he says that this business is profitable. The major challenge that he has is that he lacks machines in his business to enable him to work efficiently and effectively. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more auto spare parts to sell to his clients and expand his business. He hopes that someday he will diversify into carpentry where he will open a training school and train other young people and make them self-reliant. He says he is very passionate about what he does.

loan.use: Auto spare parts

loan.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is married with one child who is at school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a beauty salon in Kawempe working on all types of hair and providing services including relaxing, plaiting and weaving.
She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics, creams and weaves. She buys boxes of cosmetics from Kampala city shops and uses public transportation to and from shopping. Madina goes shopping once a week. Her customers are mainly women.
She has done this business for many years now and works seven days a week. Her main business challenge is transportation from her home to the Kampala city shops. She aspires to buy a plot of land and build a house for herself. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans.
Madina resides in and rents a two-room house and the family has access to electricity and no piped water. Her greatest expense in a month is rent for her house.

loan.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics, creams and weaves

loan.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce J. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, rice, beans and more at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize flour and rice to sell.
Joyce is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has two children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store to sell her goods.

loan.use: Stock more bags of maize flour and rice to sell

loan.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina B. is from the town of Trento. She is 42 years old. Lucina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lucina also raises pigs and chickens. She hopes that this new venture of hers will grow as well.
Lucina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lucina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and livestock feed. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lucina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.
About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers and livestock feed

loan.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet, a married mother of four children who are all in school, is a tailor in Nalukolongo. She makes uniforms, sweaters and t-shirts for all schools and individuals in her area. A tailor for many years now and an MCDT client for six years, Harriet works five days a week, and her main challenge is the seasonality of her business. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of school materials and threads.

Aspiring to improve her living standards, Harriet joined MCDT because she wanted additional business capital. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loan.use: To buy more rolls of school uniforms and threads

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: Purchase of 16 sacs of coal

loan.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A., from the town of Trento, is 46 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she recently started raising hogs for fattening and sale. She hopes to acquire more pigs to raise.

Luzviminda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure as well as livestock feed. This will be Luzviminda's second loan from CEVI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure as well as livestock feed

loan.name: Jonah

texts.en:
Jonah N. N. is 40 years old, married and has five children aged between 7 and 21 years old. His business is located at a busy area in Nairobi called Mukuru Kwa Njenga. The Mukuru Kwa Njenga area is served by the Kitengela branch.
His business is well-known by the name Smart Furniture Designer. He sells such items as wall units, beds, seats, side boards, tables and stools to the local people, schools and churches. He has been doing this business for 10 years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are so many people in the area doing the same business so his customers are not loyal as they are spoiled for choice. He says there is a lot of power rationing, hindering the business' performance, as well as insecurity in the area.
However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using the loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy timber for making the products that he sells to his customers. He hopes to open a big furniture shop in the future. He describes himself as hardworking and business-oriented.

loan.use: Timber

loan.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is married with five children, two of whom have completed their education up to the university level. She doesnt take care of additional family members. She changed her business enterprise from a clothing to a banana business. She owns a stall selling bananas. She sells matooke (bananas) and she hopes to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.
She has done this business for about three months now, because she had previously dealt in clothing. Besides this banana business, she also fries samosas. She sells her bananas in Nalukolongo market; she mainly sells bananas to both men and women.
Miriam works six days a week and one of the challenges she faces in her business is that bananas are seasonal. Her goals are to expand her business by going to farmers directly and also to start selling on a wholesale basis.
She decided to work with MCDT because of its good customer care.
She resides in and rents the house she stays in, and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees.

loan.use: To buy bunches of bananas

loan.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is married with a 5-year-old daughter. He sells women's clothing at the Yulana market in Pavlograd town. Andrei has been in this business for four years.
He understood quickly that to make this business successful, he needs to offer good quality items in a large assortment. That is why he invested most of his income into his inventory. Today, Andrei's business is the main source of income for his family.
Andrei would like to borrow 9,200 Ukraine Hryvnia to purchase inventory. He needs to increase the assortment of seasonal inventory before the coming fall season.

loan.use: To purchase inventory

loan.name: David

texts.en:
Most people from western Uganda have embarked on profitable business ventures using savings from their farming and milk-selling businesses. Three years ago, 54-year-old David T. went with this tide and started his retail shop in Burambara-Rukungiri. This business has been, in many ways, his recourse in dealing with the many demands that come with providing for a family and meeting the costs of operating a business.
David, a happy-go-lucky, married father of five, for the most part sells coffee, beans and ground nuts. In a month, his business generates profits to the sum of 260,000 shillings and with this loan, he wants to buy more retail stock for resale. He specifically wants to buy more beans, ground nuts and rice.

loan.use: Buying more beans, ground nuts and rice for resale

loan.name: Zeesee

texts.en:
Zeesee B. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and four children in their own ger (the traditional nomadic housing tent) in Hovd province, western Mongolia. Her husband is a gardener while her youngest daughter attends a local high school.
Zeesee began her business in 2005 with the help of her daughter and, since then, her business has been stable. With her business earnings she was enabled to rent a stall at a local market and increase the number and variety of her products.
Zeesee is requesting a 1,900,000 MNT loan to purchase a large number of plumbing parts to sell before the upcoming winter season.

loan.use: To purchase a large number of plumbing parts to sell

loan.name: Naboth

texts.en:
A. Naboth is 28 years old and married with three children. He has operated a boda-boda business in Bwamba for four years now. (A boda-boda is a cycle or motorcycle fitted with a tailor-made seat over the rear wheel).
Naboth says that it is the good service that he offers that has helped to increase and retain his customers. He says that his customers are from the local community and most of them are repeat customers and he is able to make 300,000 shillings as monthly profits. He also has a banana plantation from which he is able to produce food both for sale and for home consumption.
Naboth needs a loan to be able to buy a new motorcycle and this will increase his income base. He says that before becoming a boda-boda operator, he was a contractor working for people and now he is grateful that he owns his own business and hopes to increase the number of motorcycles for increased benefits.

loan.use: To buy another motorcycle for increased income

loan.name: Mungunhuu

texts.en:
Mungunhuu B. is 21 years old and lives with his parents and siblings in their own house in Hovd province, western Mongolia.
Mungunhuu operates a transport service in his town which he began in 2006 after purchasing a small car. He has found success with his business and has gained much experience as a driver over the years.
In 2009, Mungunhuu provided transport services to tourists and earned 3,000,000 MNT so now, with the earnings, he wants to purchase a bigger car for his business. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a newer and bigger car for his transportation business.
Mungunhuu is an honest and hardworking person who is known by his customers for his good character. For the future he hopes to continue to provide a quality and efficient transportation service.

loan.use: To purchase a newer and bigger car for his transportation business

loan.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is married with eight children and all of them are at school. She doesnt take care of any additional family members. She owns a house which has electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses are food, water and electricity.
Monica changed her business enterprise from a food stall to selling alcohol and has been in this business for a few months. She operates her business from her shop and her customers are other traders. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenge is thieves.
Monica doesnt incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work from delivery vans, which get the gin from Kabarole district.
With the loan, Monica plans to buy more jerrycans of local gin which she sells retail only. She is aiming to see her business grow big and to start selling wholesale only.

loan.use: To buy more jerycans of local gin to sell

loan.name: George

texts.en:
George T. is an individual client of Pearl Microfinance from Rukungiri. He is 52 years old and married with eight children, four of whom are still in school. George is in the business of agriculture and has banana plantations. However, as another source of income, he sells coffee, beans, sweet potatoes and cassava that he buys from other farmers and takes to the market.
George needs a loan to be able to buy manure, mulch and stake poles for his plantations so that they give him better produce. He has been in the farming business for 15 years and he inherited it from his late father. It is because of his hard work that he is where he is right now.
His plan is to expand his agriculture business and build a permanent house for his family.

loan.use: Buying manure, mulch and stake poles for his plantations so that they give him better produce

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 50-year-old single woman from Lebanon living with her mother and one sister. She has owned a toy shop in her town since 1996 and sells all type of games in addition to kids stories and books. She has been working hard in her store to be able, with the cooperation of her sister, to provide better life conditions for her sick mother. In order to fulfill her business objectives and increase the liquidity of her services, she is asking for a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.al. to increase her store purchases before the coming holidays because her sales rise during this period and she has to be prepared. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in her picture, not indicating her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in Microfinance. At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loan.use: Increase her store purchases

loan.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin is married with three children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes rent and school fees.
Kevin owns a restaurant in Kawempe selling traditional food and has been in this business for many years. She buys her foodstuffs from Kalerwe market and uses public transport to and from shopping. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale, working seven days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and seasonality. She doesnt have any side business.
Kevin wants to use this loan to buy a deep freezer. She is aspiring to educate her children up to university. She decided to work with MCDT because of its low interest rate.

loan.use: To buy a deep freezer

loan.name: El Hadj

texts.fr: N en 1974, Monsieur El Hadj S. est un maon trs connu dans la ville de This. Il gagne beaucoup de march de par ses connaissances et son travail jug de srieux par ses clients. Il souhaitait un prt de 125 000 FCFA pour acheter des planches de coffrage afin d'augmenter son stock insuffisant de planches. Enfin, Monsieur El Hadj S. est mari et compte sur son mtier pour rgler tous ses besoins et ceux de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1974, Mr. El Hadj S. is a very well-known mason in the town of This. He wins many contracts because of his experience and the seriousness he displays in his work, according to customers. He is requesting a loan of 125,000 FCFA to buy formwork planking to increase his insufficient stock of planks. Finally, Mr. El Hadj S. is married and relies on his job to cover all of his needs and those of his family.

Translated from French by Ren McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: purchase construction materials

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To purchase necessary tools for his shop

loan.name: Samuel

texts.fr: B. Samuel, ne Kigali secteur Muhima dans la province de ville de Kigali du Rwanda, il est mari, il a 4 enfants, il a 40 ans, son ain a 12 ans et son dernier enfant 5 ans et son niveau dducation est primaire. Il habite Kicukiro avec sa famille. Tous ces enfants vont lcole. Son pouse fait le commerce de dtail en boutique pour aider son mari de faire vivre sa famille et pouvoir amliorer les conditions de vie de celle-ci. Il effectue ce commerce de transport des personnes sur moto a Kigali .Il vient de contracter un prt au sein dAmasezerano pour acheter le rservoir de sa moto pour remplacer le vieux rservoir. Il fait les pargnes, une partie du profit est pargne pour les tudes de ses enfants et supporter la capacit financire de sa femme. Il a pu construire une maison grce aux pargnes continuelles.
texts.en:
B. Samuel was born in Kigali, in the Muhima sector, in the province of Kigali City, Rwanda. He is married and has four children. He is 40 years old. His eldest child is 12, and his last child is 5. Samuel has a primary school education. He lives with his family in Kicukiro. All of his children go to school. His wife has a retail store to help her husband provide for the family and to be able to improve living conditions. Samuel has a business transporting people on his motorbike in Kigali. He just signed a loan with the micro-finance institution Amasezerano to buy a gas tank for his motorbike to replace the old one. He is saving money. Part of his profit is saved for his children's schooling and for supporting his wife's finances. He was able to build a house, thanks to the steady savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buying a fuel tank for his motorbike

loan.name: Kweyamba Women's Namawojjolo 2, Lugazi Group

texts.en:
N. Daisy is a 28-year-old mother of one, operating a business selling soft drinks in Nawawojjollo, Lugazi. A friend helped her to start up in business after she prevailed upon her to dispense with the idea of depending wholly on her husband for everything.
Daisy has been running her business for the last two years and, in a sense, has been successful in as far as making her business function well. Her close personal involvement and proactivity in the decision-making processes aimed at helping her business grow, have been her towers of strength. In a week, her business generates her profits that total up to 35,000 shillings.
With this loan, Daisy envisages being in a position to buy more soft drinks and bottled fruit juice for her business. She will resell it to earn more revenue.

loan.use: To buy more soft drinks like sodas and bottled fruit juices to sell

loan.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana S. was born in 1966 and lives in Ijevan city with her 13-year-old son. Svetlana's husband has been missing for several years, but she doesn't lose hope of finding him some day!
Since 2005 Svetlana has run her own shop where she sells food, household goods and clothes. With the profit from her business she keeps her small family, supports her business, and also was able to buy a computer.
To increase her income, Svetlana intends to start to manage an Internet club. Thus, now, she asks for a 550,000 AMD loan which will enable her to buy two more computers. Her son has good computer skills so, after his lessons, he will help his mother in her new occupation.

loan.use: To buy two computers for her new Internet business

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 23 years old and married, and she has one child. She graduated from primary school.
The borrower is a tailor. She will use this loan to purchase a domestic sewing machine and cloth. The borrower has had a sewing business for two years and acquired a great deal of experience in her work. The borrower has a good reputation and is capable of attracting many clients.

loan.use: To buy a sewing machine and cloth

loan.name: Tsedev

texts.en:
Tsedev N. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two children in their own ger (the traditional housing tent) in Hovd province, western Mongolia. He and his family have been living in Hovd for over three years.
Tsedev and his wife, Bertsetseg, manage a clothing trading business at the local market in their town. They started their business in 2007 and since then they have gained much progress with it. Their earnings have enabled them to buy a new container at the local market from which they sell the clothing.
For the future, Tsedev hopes to use his experience to operate his own clothing store. He wants to sell a wider variety of clothes to meet all of his customers needs. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes to sell at retail prices.

loan.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loan.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two children. She runs a small business selling womens clothing in one kiosk and sunflower oil and related products in an adjacent kiosk.
Olga has been in the retail business for eleven years. When she started her business the competition was low. Later she decided to diversify her retail business into two parts clothing and food. This helped Olga to maintain a steady income despite high competition.
This business is the only source of income for Olgas family. She would like to obtain a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase one more kiosk. She hopes to increase her turnover and make additional income.

loan.use: To purchase one more kiosk

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To print out language training DVDs and textbooks

loan.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with children all of them in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Rose owns a store at her home in Kanyanya selling charcoal.
